results.title: Equalibrium
results.brief_description: One of the layers of this Equalibrium consists of an image of a Sufi like spinning dancer in a white lab coat. This out-take from an earlier film, Phonogramme, had somehow become splattered with a kind of mould that formed small flower like shapes in the frame. It is combined with a loop of hand-painted film which deteriorates slowly each time the loop repeats.

results.title: The Rice ladle
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Japanese women these days face difficulties, especially in the professions as society emphasises the traditional role as the home-maker. Looks at a widow working as a cook’s assistant and a girl studying to be a pop star.

results.title: The Career escalator
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey, Australia Japan Foundation and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
We meet Yuichi, a ‘ronin’ student studying for his final entrance exams to a top university, and Oka, a senior executive at Mitsubishi. The intense competition and unique processes of commercial life and the structure of the Japanese education system from kindergarten to tertiary level are featured in this film. Narrated by Peter Gwynne. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Lifetime employment
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Manufactured exports are basic to Japan’s survival. Conditions of industrial employment are shown particularly in the automotive industry.

results.title: A Working couple
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Most Japanese live in the big cities, many of them are salaried company workers, living in housing estates and traveling long distances to work. For many people, life is a struggle. This focuses of Mr Yokohama, a professional office employee and his wife who runs a chemist. Their lives provide an insight as to what its like to live in Tokyo, with a population of twelve million.

results.title: Animal Farm by George Orwell. The Grapes of wrath by John Steinbeck
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I couldn’t put it down - hooked on books. Classroom classics”.
Classroom Classics utilises material from film versions of literary works to encourage students to seek out, read, and analyse intelligently books they are studying in class. In this episode two important political novels of the twentieth century are discussed. George Orwell’s “Animal Farm” is a caustic satire about the corruption of idealism. John Steinbeck’s “The Grapes of Wrath” is a powerful novel about the effect of the 1930’s Depression on the American poor. Both novels are analysed in relation to the historic conditions that fed the writers’ art, passion and anger.

results.title: Raw fish and pickle
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey, Australia Japan Foundation and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Depicts life in a traditional rural province - Iwate Prefecture - and looks at attempts to improve Japan’s self-sufficiency in food. Also shows traditional fishing songs, traditional dancing and the Morioka Snow Festival. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Diary of Anne Frank. A Separate peace by John Knowles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I couldn’t put it down - hooked on books. Classroom classics”.
Classroom Classics utilises material from film versions of literary works to encourage students to seek out, read, and analyse intelligently books they are studying in class. This video explores “The Diary of Anne Frank” and John Knowles’ “A Separate Peace”. The commentary concentrates on questions of character and motivation.

results.title: Lord of the flies by William Golding; The adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I couldn’t put it down - hooked on books. Classroom classics”.
Clips from the film versions of these two seminal novels help students understand the plot, characters and essence of the stories. The narrator poses questions which hopefully stimulate the student to think more deeply about the issues tackled in the novels. “Lord of the flies” is described as, simultaneously an adventure story and an exploration of human nature, and good and evil, posing the question “Is human goodness an individual matter?”. “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” could be seen as the true beginning of American literature, and poses questions about freedom, responsibility and individuality.
